Before diving into modern deployment (Kubernetes, containerization etc.,), let's rewind a bit and understand the evolution of application deployment.
documents.s: Back to history - Old Deployment World

documents.t: Imagine a powerful physical server: 12 cores, 32 GB RAM. You deploy one Java or Node or Python app on it. The app uses maybe 20-30% CPU and 10% RAM. You could definitely deploy another app, but Conflicts in packages, runtime versions, ports, etc. If one app crashes, it can sometimes affect the entire system. Security isolation is weak. This leads to huge resource wastage This problem remained for years: How to better utilize a single machine safely ?

A hypervisor (VMware, Hyper-V, KVM, VirtualBox) is a special management layer that Sits on top of raw hardware Slices CPU, RAM, Disk, Network & more Creates fully isolated environment This environment maps to Virtual Machines
documents.s: The first solution: Hypervisors & Virtual Machines (VM's)

documents.t: Strong isolation (each VM has its own full OS) Different apps can run different OS versions Safer and more flexible than just installing apps directly on the host

Each VM runs its own full OS (more GBs of RAM needed per VM) Slow to start (minutes) Poor density - fewer VMs per server This made people ask the next big question: How do we isolate apps like VM's, but make it super lightweight?

Instead of packaging a full OS, containers reuse the host machines OS kernel. They isolate only File system Processes Network Resources (CPU, memory, etc.) This isolation is achieved using Linux features like namespaces and cgroups. tip Learn more about Linux kernel namespaces and cgroups

Containerization concept is the foundation of modern DevOps. Modern DevOps cannot be explained without understanding containerization. Cloud deployments, microservices, CI/CD pipelines all rely heavily on this concept. Containers ‚â† Docker. Docker is just one container engine. Others include containerd, CRI-O, Podman, LXC Cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP) internally run their services using container technologies.
Docker didn‚Äôt invent containerization & Linux containers existed earlier (LXC, Solaris Zones, BSD Jails).
Easy to build Easy to ship Easy to run & portable Easy to share (Docker Hub)
Extremely lightweight & consistent Start in seconds Easy to scale, portable & efficient Cloud platforms adopted them rapidly
documents.s: Why containers became a game changer

documents.t: You need strong isolation You require different operating systems on the same hardware You need to run legacy applications that require a full OS environment You want to run applications that need direct access to hardware or specialized drivers

You want lightweight and fast application deployment You need to scale applications quickly and efficiently You are developing cloud-native or microservice applications You want to maximize resource utilization on a single host

Earlier, apps were deployed directly on physical servers, causing conflicts, poor isolation and wasted resources. Virtual Machines (VMs) improved isolation by giving each app its own OS, but they were heavy, slow and resource-intensive. Containers emerged as a lightweight solution that shares the host OS kernel while isolating processes, filesystem and networks. Docker popularized containers by making them easy to build, run, share and deploy. Containers became essential in DevOps, microservices and cloud systems due to their speed, portability and efficiency. Use VMs when strong isolation or different OS types are needed. Use containers when you need fast, scalable and resource-efficient application deployment.

Let's explore Docker, the most popular containerization platform. Docker is a most popular containerization platform. It makes it easy to build, ship and run applications in isolated environments called containers. It uses lightweight isolation (not full OS virtualization), making containers fast, portable, and efficient. Docker popularized containers with Docker Engine Docker CLI Docker Hub (image registry) Docker Desktop

The easiest and most beginner-friendly approach is using Docker Desktop. tip Download Docker Desktop from the official site It comes with: Docker Engine Docker CLI Easy system UI Automatic updates toggle & much more.

After installation open your docker desktop app and sign in with your Docker Hub account. warning Create a new Docker Hub account using your personal email if you don't have one by following this link

A simple test command to run in your terminal to verify Docker installation docker run hello-world If everything is set up correctly, Docker Pulls the hello-world image from docker hub Runs a container Prints a success message This confirms your engine, networking and CLI all work.

Image ‚Üí Blueprint (template) for containers (like a class in OOP). Container ‚Üí Running instance of an image (like an object). Registry ‚Üí Storage for images (Docker Hub, ECR, ACR, GCR). Dockerfile ‚Üí Instructions to build your own image. Engine ‚Üí The runtime that actually runs your containers.

A Docker image is a lightweight, standalone, executable package that contains everything needed to run a piece of software like application code, runtime ,libraries, environment variables & configuration files Layered Architecture‚Äã Docker images are built layer by layer, where each instruction in a Dockerfile (such as FROM, COPY, RUN) creates a new layer. Layers are stacked to form the final image. They are cached, improving build speed. If a layer doesn‚Äôt change, Docker reuses it in future builds. Immutable‚Äã Once an image is built, it cannot be modified. Any change creates a new layer or a new image version. This immutability ensures consistency If it runs on my machine, it will run everywhere. Portable‚Äã Images can run on any machine that has a compatible Docker engine. You can develop on Windows, test on Linux, deploy on Kubernetes the same image. This guarantees environment consistency.

A Docker container is the runtime instance of a Docker image. If an image is a class, the container is an object Isolated‚Äã Containers run in their own isolated environment Separate filesystem Separate process space Network namespace Resource limits (CPU, memory) Ephemeral‚Äã By default, containers are temporary, that means a container stops, its filesystem changes are lost (unless using volumes).
Let's practice some essential Docker commands to run, manage images and containers.
docker pull # Download an image docker images # List all images docker rmi # Delete an image

docker run # Run a container in the foreground docker run -p 8080:80 # Map host port ‚Üí container port docker run -d # Run in detached mode (run in background) docker run --name myapp # Assign a name to your container
docker ps # Running containers docker ps -a # All containers (including stopped)
docker stop <id> # Stop a running container docker rm <id> # Remove a stopped container

docker exec -it <id> sh # Open interactive shell inside container docker exec -it <id> /bin/bash # Open interactive bash inside container docker exec <id> ls /usr/share/nginx/html # print files in container
documents.s: Run a Command inside Container (Debugging purpose)

documents.t: docker container prune # Remove stopped containers docker image prune # Remove unused dangling images tip A dangling image in Docker is an image that has no name, no tag and is not used by any container. It is an unused leftover, usually created after a build or update. Docker keeps them to save time during future builds. docker image prune -a # Remove all unused images docker system prune # Remove unused data (do at risk!) important Docker system prune is a cleanup command that removes unused Docker data to free disk space. It is safe, but you must understand what it deletes. It removes Dangling images Stopped containers, Unused networks (not default ones) Build cache tip Explore more commands from the official Docker CLI reference Cheat sheet - Docker Cheat Sheet Another best place to learn is from CLI itself - docker <command> --help

Docker installed and running on your machine. Verify by running docker --version in your terminal. Download Node.js from nodejs.org. Verify installation by running node -v and npm -v in your terminal. Download Python from python.org. Verify installation by running python --version and pip --version in your terminal.
In this exercise, you'll containerize a simple Node.js backend application using Docker.

Create a new directory for your project and navigate into it mkdir node-app cd node-app Initialize a new Node.js project npm init -y Install Express.js (framework for building web applications) npm install express Create an index.js file with the following content const express = require("express"); const app = express(); const port = process.env.PORT || 4000; app.get("/", (req, res) => { res.send("Hello from Node.js!"); }); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(`Server listening at http://localhost:${port}`); }); Test the application locally node index.js Open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:4000. You should see "Hello from Node.js!" displayed. Stop the server by pressing Ctrl + C in your terminal. Create a Dockerfile in the root of your project with the following content # Use an official Node.js runtime as a parent image FROM node:24-alpine # Set the working directory in the container WORKDIR /app # Copy package.json and package-lock.json COPY package*.json ./ # Install dependencies RUN npm install # Copy the rest of the application code by ignoring files in .dockerignore COPY . . # Expose the port the app runs on EXPOSE 4000 # Define the command to run the app CMD ["node", "index.js"] Create a .dockerignore file to exclude unnecessary files from the Docker image node_modules Dockerfile .dockerignore
documents.s: Step 1: Set up the Node.js Application

documents.t: Open your terminal and navigate to the project directory. Run the following command to build the Docker image docker build -t node-app .

After the image is built, run the container using the following command docker run --name node-app -p 5000:4000 node-app Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:5000. You should see "Hello from Node.js!" displayed. To stop the container, go back to your terminal and press Ctrl + C. Congratulations! You've successfully containerized a Node.js backend application using Docker.
In this exercise, you'll containerize a simple Python FastAPI backend application using Docker.

Create a new directory for your project and navigate into it mkdir python-app cd python-app Create and activate a virtual environment (optional but recommended) python -m venv .venv .venv\Scripts\activate Install FastAPI and Uvicorn pip install "fastapi[standard]" Create a main.py file with the following content from fastapi import FastAPI app = FastAPI() @app.get("/") def read_root(): return { "message": "Hello World from FastAPI!" } Test the application locally fastapi run main.py Open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:8000. You should see {"message": "Hello from FastAPI!"} displayed. Stop the server by pressing Ctrl + C in your terminal. Create a Dockerfile in the root of your project with the following content # Use an official Python runtime as a parent image FROM python:3.12-slim # Set the working directory in the container WORKDIR /app # Copy requirements.txt COPY requirements.txt ./ # Install dependencies RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt # Copy the rest of the application code by ignoring files in .dockerignore COPY . . # Expose the port the app runs on EXPOSE 8000 # Define the command to run the app CMD ["fastapi", "run", "main.py" , "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"] Create a requirements.txt file to list the dependencies fastapi[standard] Create a .dockerignore file to exclude unnecessary files from the Docker image __pycache__ *.pyc venv Dockerfile .dockerignore
documents.s: Step 1: Set up the FastAPI Application

documents.t: Open your terminal and navigate to the project directory. Run the following command to build the Docker image docker build -t fastapi-app .
documents.s: Step 2: Build the Python FastAPI Docker Image

documents.t: After the image is built, run the container using the following command docker run --name fastapi-app -p 8000:8000 fastapi-app Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:8000. You should see {"message": "Hello from FastAPI!"} displayed. To stop the container, go back to your terminal and press Ctrl + C. Congratulations! You've successfully containerized a Python FastAPI backend application using Docker.
documents.s: Step 3: Run the Python FastAPI Docker Container

documents.t: In this exercise, you'll containerize a simple React frontend application using Docker.

Create a new application using Vite npm create vite@latest my-react-app -- --template react Navigate into the project directory cd my-react-app Install dependencies npm install Test the application locally by running the development server npm run dev Open your browser and navigate to the URL provided in the terminal (usually http://localhost:5173). You should see the default Vite React application running. Stop the server by pressing Ctrl + C in your terminal. Create a Dockerfile in the root of your project with the following content (Introducing Multi-stage builds) # Stage 1: Build the React application FROM node:24-alpine AS build # Set the working directory in the container WORKDIR /app # Copy package.json and package-lock.json COPY package*.json ./ # Install dependencies RUN npm install # Copy the rest of the application code by ignoring files in .dockerignore COPY . . # Build the React application for production RUN npm run build # Stage 2: Serve the built application using a lightweight web server FROM nginx:alpine # Copy the built files from the previous stage to Nginx's html directory COPY --from=build /app/dist /usr/share/nginx/html # Expose port 80 EXPOSE 80 # Start Nginx server CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"] Create a .dockerignore file to exclude unnecessary files from the Docker image node_modules build Dockerfile .dockerignore tip Use multi-stage builds in your Dockerfile to optimize the image size by separating the build environment from the runtime environment. With multi-stage builds, you use multiple FROM statements in your Dockerfile. Each FROM instruction can use a different base, and each of them begins a new stage of the build. You can selectively copy artifacts from one stage to another, leaving behind everything you don't want in the final image. Learn more about multi-stage builds from the official Docker documentation: Docker Multi-Stage Builds
documents.s: Step 1: Set up the React Application

documents.t: Open your terminal and navigate to the project directory. Run the following command to build the Docker image docker build -t my-react-app .
documents.s: Step 2: Build the React Docker Image

documents.t: After the image is built, run the container using the following command docker run --name my-react-app -p 6001:80 my-react-app Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:6001. You should see the default Vite React application running. To stop the container, go back to your terminal and press Ctrl + C. Congratulations! You've successfully containerized a React frontend application using Docker.
documents.s: Step 3: Run the React Docker Container

documents.t: Use official lightweight base images like alpine or slim variants to reduce image size. Leverage multi-stage builds to reduce final image size. Use .dockerignore to exclude unnecessary files from the build context. Install only application production dependencies in the final image. Remove dev dependencies (e.g., using npm ci --only=production for Node.js & for python pip install --no-dev). Every RUN, COPY and ADD creates a layer. Combining commands with && reduces layers. Regularly update base images to get security patches and improvements. Use specific version tags for base images instead of latest to ensure consistency. tip More tips on best practices can be found in the official Docker documentation: Best practices for writing Docker files Other resource: Docker Image Size Optimization
documents.s: Best Practices for building Docker Images

documents.t: In this section, we will explore two important concepts in Docker Docker Networks - how containers communicate Docker Volumes - how containers persist data Both are essential for building real-world applications with multiple containers (database + backend + frontend) need to communicate and persist data safely.

Docker networks allow containers to Communicate with each other. Communicate with the outside world Stay isolated from containers they should not interact with By default, every container is attached to a specific network type.
Docker supports multiple network drivers, each designed for a different use case.

A private internal network created by Docker on the host machine. Containers get an internal IP Containers can talk to each other using container names & IP's Default bridge network only allows communication between containers via IP addresses, not container names Best suited for local development and single-host setups Example: docker network ls docker network create my-bridge docker run --network my-bridge -d --name c1 busybox sleep 300 docker run --network my-bridge -d --name c2 busybox sleep 300 docker exec -it c1 ping c2

The container shares the host machine‚Äôs network stack. No isolation between host and container Useful when container needs high network performance Best for apps using custom network drivers, VPN tools, monitoring agents, etc. Example: docker run --network host nginx
The container has no network interface except the loopback. No internet No communication & fully isolated Useful for security or batch jobs Example: docker run --network none busybox ifconfig
Allows containers running on different hosts to communicate Used for distributed microservices Automatically encrypted depending on config

Containers are ephemeral - when a container is removed, its internal data is lost. Volumes help solve this by providing persistent storage. Persist data beyond container lifecycle Share data between containers Decouple data from the container image Commonly used for databases, logs, user uploads, etc.

Managed by Docker. Example: docker volume create mydata docker volume inspect mydata docker run -it -v mydata:/test busybox sh echo "Hello, Volume!" > /test/hello.txt exit docker run -it -v mydata:/test busybox sh cat /test/hello.txt

Mounts a file or directory from the host machine into the container. Example: mkdir -p /path/on/host echo "Hello from Host!" > /path/on/host/hostfile.txt docker run -it -v /path/on/host:/data busybox sh cat /data/hostfile.txt echo "Hello from Container!" > /data/containerfile.txt exit cat /path/on/host/containerfile.txt
Use Volumes for most cases - easier to manage, portable, storage maintained by Docker and optimized for Docker. Use Bind Mounts for development - allows syncing code between host and container.
documents.s: When to Use Volumes vs Bind Mounts

documents.t: Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container applications. It is the key to unlocking a streamlined and efficient development and deployment experience

Simplified Configuration: Define all your services, networks, and volumes in a single docker-compose.yml file. Multi-Container Applications: Easily manage applications that require multiple services (e.g., web server, database, cache). Isolation: Each service runs in its own container, ensuring that dependencies do not conflict. Lets see how Docker Compose works for a simple web application.

Service: A service is a containerized application defined in the docker-compose.yml file. Network: Docker Compose automatically creates a network for your services to communicate. Volume: Persistent storage that can be shared between services. Project: A project is a collection of services defined in a docker-compose.yml file.

Create a new docker-compose.yml file in your directory parallel to the frontend & backend directories. Write the docker-compose.yml file with the following content version: "3.9" name: my-web-app services: frontend: build: ./my-react-app container_name: frontend restart: always ports: - "6001:80" depends_on: - backend networks: - my-custom-network backend: build: ./node-app container_name: backend restart: always ports: - "5000:4000" depends_on: - database networks: - my-custom-network database: image: postgres:16-alpine container_name: database restart: always environment: POSTGRES_USER: user POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password POSTGRES_DB: postgres ports: - "5432:5432" volumes: - pg-data:/var/lib/postgresql/data networks: - my-custom-network volumes: pg-data: networks: my-custom-network: driver: bridge Note: This is just an example. The frontend, backend & database are not connected Start the services using Docker Compose: docker compose up Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:6001 to see the frontend Stop the services: docker compose down
documents.s: Exercise: Creating a Docker Compose File

documents.t: Now that you have learned the basics of Docker, Dockerfile and Docker Compose, it's time to see how everything fits together. When someone starts their container journey, everything begins simple. You have an application. You package it in a container. You run it with Docker. Life is good! note Your app can‚Äôt live on localhost forever. At some point, you‚Äôve got to let your app spread its wings, escape the 127.0.0.1 bubble and meet real humans who click things they shouldn‚Äôt & raise bugs. As the application grows, the needs grow too. This is the natural evolution that any dev team go through.
Every team starts with a single container docker build -t myapp . docker run -p 3000:3000 myapp This works perfectly for local development, simple applications & quick demos.
documents.s: 1. The Beginning: single Container with Docker

documents.t: What if you have multiple services? A backend, frontend, database, Redis, message queue etc., running with 10 docker run commands becomes unmanageable.

The developer now organizes everything using a docker-compose.yml. With just one command docker compose up -d They get multiple services, networking out-of-the-box, volumes for data, easy environment variable management At this stage, many real-world projects stop here and there‚Äôs nothing wrong with that If your app is small/medium and runs on a single machine, App Service, VM or EC2, Docker Compose is enough and it‚Äôs a perfect solution. But then, the project grows again‚Ä¶
documents.s: 2. Growing Up: Multi-Container Apps with Docker Compose

documents.t: The team now faces problems, like docker containers crashed, VM Crashed & affected the app availability. They need high availability & they want failover when a container crashes They want multiple VMs/nodes to cope with increased traffic & availability Docker Compose cannot do this. Docker Swarm acts as the live saver.
documents.s: 3. The Demand for Scaling: Enter Docker Swarm

documents.t: Multi-node cluster (managers + workers) Service scaling Built-in load balancing Secrets management etc., Example Swarm deployment docker swarm init docker stack deploy -c docker-compose.yml myapp Swarm uses the same Docker Compose syntax, so the learning curve is low.
important However, as systems become more complex having lot of microservices, distributed systems, enterprise SLAs Docker Swarm eventually hits limits.

The organization now wants Auto-scaling based on load High availability Self-healing infrastructure (failover mechanisms) Advanced networking policies Ingress controllers Observability at scale Canary deployments & blue-green releases Much more.. This is where Kubernetes enters. Kubernetes is not a replacement for Docker or container runtimes, it's an orchestration system that runs containers at massive scale. With Kubernetes, you get Cluster-level scheduling Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) Node health checks & self-healing Service discovery & load balancing ConfigMaps & Secrets Rollout's & rollbacks Enterprise-grade extensions (Istio, Prometheus, ArgoCD, etc.) And much more.. This is why nearly every enterprise company chooses Kubernetes for Enterprise scale High availability Multi-region deployments Cloud-native architectures tip Enterprise organization will typically run around thousands to millions of containers. And Kubernetes is designed to handle this scale efficiently.

There is no wrong choice. You choose the tool based on your project‚Äôs needs. If small project, one VM + few services ‚Üí Docker Compose If simple to medium project requiring multi-node ‚Üí Docker Swarm If large-scale, enterprise, microservices ‚Üí Kubernetes tip Docker swarm is still catching up with features compared to Kubernetes. At present, its a good middle ground for small to medium projects without Kubernetes complexity.

Kubernetes (K8s) is an open-source container orchestration platform designed to automate the deployment, scaling and management of containerized applications. It was originally developed by Google and is now maintained by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF). tip Kubernetes is called k8's because there are 8 letters between the 'K' and the 'S'.
There are multiple ways to install k8's depending on your use case

Lets install minikube in your local machine for learning purpose. Follow the instructions here. Note use the powershell instructions for windows machine. After installation run the below commands to start minikube minikube start --nodes 3 After that run minikube status to check the status of the cluster minikube status Install kubectl command line tool by following instructions here. Verify kubectl is working fine by running kubectl get nodes kubectl get pods -A We will talk about kubectl commands in detail in later sections. Don't worry if you don't understand the output now.

Node: A node is a worker machine in Kubernetes, which can be a physical or virtual machine (1 node = 1 VM) Pod: The smallest and simplest Kubernetes unit. A pod represents a single instance of a running process and can contain one or more containers. (Assume pod is wrapper over container for now)

Now that we have a running k8's cluster, we can deploy our containerized applications to it. But how do we tell k8's what to deploy and how to deploy it? There are two main ways: Imperative commands using kubectl (not recommended for production) Declarative configuration files (YAML/JSON) (recommended for production) Lets see an example of declarative configuration .yaml file to deploy a simple hello world pod. apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: nginx-pod-1 labels: env: demo spec: containers: - name: nginx-pod-1 image: nginx:latest

First lets look into the imperative way of deploying the pod using kubectl kubectl run --image=nginx nginx-pod Now verify the pod is created and running using the below command kubectl get pods kubectl get pods -o wide To see the logs of the pod run the below command kubectl logs nginx-pod To see the logs in realtime use the -f flag or tail the logs kubectl logs -f nginx-pod To see detailed information about the pod run the below command kubectl describe pod nginx-pod kubectl describe pod/nginx-pod Now that we have seen the imperative way of deploying a pod, lets see the declarative way using the above yaml file. Save the above yaml file as pod.yaml and run the below command to create the pod kubectl create -f pod.yaml Verify the pod is created and running using the below command kubectl get pods Typing the yaml file is time consuming. So we can leverage a shortcut, the dry run option to generate the yaml file from the imperative command. kubectl run nginx-3 --image=nginx --dry-run=client -o yaml > pod2.yaml Now you can edit the pod2.yaml file to add more configurations if needed and create the pod using the below command kubectl create -f pod2.yaml To edit an existing pod use the below command kubectl edit pod nginx-pod You can also edit the yaml file and apply the changes using the below command kubectl apply -f pod.yaml Similar to docker exec you can also exec into the pod using the below command kubectl exec -it nginx-pod -- sh minikube kubectl -- exec nginx-pod -it -- sh

Now that we have a basic understanding of k8's and have deployed our first pod, let's look into the high level architecture of k8's The main components of k8's architecture are Master Node (Control Plane) Can be multiple nodes for high availability Worker Node (Can be one or many nodes) Cluster is made up of multiple nodes (Master + Worker nodes) The Master Node consists of the following components API Server: The front-end for the Kubernetes control plane. It exposes the Kubernetes API & is the entry point for all the REST commands used to control the cluster. etcd: A consistent and highly-available key value store used as Kubernetes' backing store for all cluster data. Controller Manager: Runs controller processes. A controller is a small program that watches the cluster and makes sure things are in the desired state (E.g node controller, pod controller etc.,) Scheduler: Watches for newly created Pods with no assigned node, and selects a node for them to run on. Cloud Controller Manager: Lets you link your cluster into your cloud provider's API and separates out the components that interact with that cloud platform from components that just interact with your cluster. The Worker Node consists of the following components Kubelet: An agent that runs on each node in the cluster. It makes sure that containers are running in a Pod & kubelet communicates with the master node. Kube-Proxy: A network proxy that runs on each node in your cluster, it maintains network rules & handles routing of traffic to Pods from inside or outside the cluster. Container Runtime (CRI): The software that is responsible for running containers (E.g containerd, docker etc.,) Pods: The smallest and simplest Kubernetes object. A pod represents a single instance of a running process in your cluster and can contain one or more containers.

In the previous section we saw a high level overview of k8's architecture & also pods. But pods are just one of the many components in k8's. And like we discussed in docker section, pods cannot solve all the problems of deployment. For example pods are ephemeral in nature & if a pod goes down due to some reason, there is no way to bring it back up again. Also pods do not provide features like scaling. To solve these problems, k8's provides higher level abstractions on top of pods like ReplicaSets, Deployments, Services, StatefulSets, Storage etc.,

A Deployment is a higher level abstraction that manages a set of identical pods. It ensures that a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time. If a pod goes down or crashed, the Deployment automatically creates a new pod to replace it, ensuring high availability. Deployments also split pods across multiple nodes for fault tolerance. You can also use Deployments to perform rolling updates to your application, allowing you to update your application without downtime. Deployment also help us with rollout undo capabilities in case of bad deployments. Generally replica sets are not created directly, instead they are created and managed by Deployments. The selector field in Deployment helps to identify the pods that belong to the Deployment. So the matching happens based on labels.

First let' clean up the previous pod kubectl delete pod nginx-pod-1 kubectl delete pod --all Let's create a deployment using imperative command kubectl create deployment nginx-deployment --image=nginx --replicas=3 Now verify the deployment and pods are created and running using the below commands kubectl get pods -o wide Now lets delete one of the pods and see if deployment brings it back up kubectl delete pod <pod-name> Now verify the pods again using the below command & this proves that deployment controller is bringing back the desired state kubectl get pods -o wide You can see the pods are spread across multiple nodes for fault tolerance. Note this depends on the number of nodes in your cluster. If you have only one node, all pods will be scheduled on the same node. Also if there are not enough resources (CPU or RAM) in the nodes, pods will be scheduled on the same node. Now let run this command kubectl get deployments kubectl describe deployment <name> One thing to note here is if we need to delete the pod, we either edit the deployment to reduce the number of replicas or delete the deployment itself. kubectl scale deployment <name> --replicas=2 kubectl delete deployment <name>

Let's create a deployment using declarative way using the below command kubectl create deployment nginx-deployment --image=nginx --replicas=3 --dry-run=client -o yaml > deploy.yaml The above command creates a deployment yaml file named deploy.yaml with 3 replicas of nginx pods. Now let's apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deploy.yaml Now verify the deployment and pods are created and running using the below commands kubectl get pods -o wide Adding deployment yaml for reference apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: nginx-deployment labels: app: nginx-deployment spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: nginx-deployment template: metadata: labels: app: nginx-deployment spec: containers: - image: nginx name: nginx

Use Branch Protection Rules: Enforce rules on branches to ensure code quality and prevent unauthorized changes. This includes requiring pull requests for changes, enforcing status checks, and restricting who can push to the branch. Code Owners & PR Templates: Use CODEOWNERS files to define who is responsible for code in specific directories. This helps in ensuring that the right people review changes. Also, use pull request templates to guide contributors on how to submit changes. Remove unused branches: Regularly clean up branches that are no longer needed. This helps in keeping the repository organized and reduces clutter. Use the git branch -d <branch-name> command to delete local branches, and git push origin --delete <branch-name> to delete remote branches.

Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is one of the core protocols of the Internet Protocol (IP) suite. It provides reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data between applications running on hosts communicating over an IP network. TCP is widely used for applications that require guaranteed delivery, such as web browsing, email, and file transfers.
How to Increase Network TCP/IP Connections in Linux 1,000,000 Concurrent TCP Connections EC2 Tuning for +1M TCP Connections using Linux Redhat TCP Window Scaling

Changing the remote Git repository URL in a local Git repository can be done using the git remote set-url command. This is useful when you want to switch from one remote repository to another, such as changing from a personal repository to an organizational one. git remote set-url origin https://sathish-thangavel@github.com/<org>/<repo>.git
If you want to set the local Git username and email for the repository, you can use the following commands: git config user.name "<Your Name>" git config user.email "<Your Email>"
documents.s: Set local git username and email

documents.t: If you want to set the global Git username and email, which will apply to all repositories on your machine, you can use the following commands: git config --global user.name "<Your Name>" git config --global user.email "<Your Email>"
documents.s: Set global git username and email

documents.t: To verify that the remote URL has been changed, you can use the following command git remote -v

Delete all GitHub Actions workflow runs from a repository using PowerShell and the GitHub CLI. While GitHub‚Äôs retention settings only clear the logs inside workflows, they don‚Äôt remove the workflow entries themselves. To solve this, we can write a PowerShell script as highlighted in the below blog Source Blog : Delete all github workflow runs using powershell Create a powershell script named run.ps1 param ( [string]$Owner, [string]$Repo ) if (-not (Get-Command gh -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue)) { Write-Host "GitHub CLI (gh) is not installed. Please install it from https://cli.github.com/" -ForegroundColor Red exit 1 } if (-not $Owner -or -not $Repo) { Write-Host "Usage: .\run.ps1 -Owner <GitHub-Owner> -Repo <GitHub-Repo>" -ForegroundColor Yellow exit 1 } $workflowRuns = gh api repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs --paginate --jq '.workflow_runs[].id' foreach ($runId in $workflowRuns) { Write-Host "Deleting workflow run ID: $runId" gh api repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs/$runId -X DELETE } Write-Host "All workflow runs have been deleted." This script does a few things: Accepts the owner and the repository as arguments. Run it as: .\run.ps1 -Owner <GitHub-Owner> -Repo <GitHub-Repo>. Avoids hard-coding values so it can run across different repositories easily. Checks if the GitHub CLI (gh) is installed by calling Get-Command on gh. Validates that both the owner and repository name are provided. Retrieves all workflow runs by calling the repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs endpoint with --paginate to fetch all pages of results. For each workflow run ID, sends a DELETE request to repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs/$runId to remove the run. Before running the script, make sure you‚Äôre authenticated with your GitHub account: gh auth login Once you logged in, call the script with a repo to which you have access and where you want to erase all workflow runs. Example command: .\run.ps1 -Owner glibnub -Repo waittimes-aggregator All the workflow runs will be deleted after this command

You have just learned the basics of Docusaurus and made some changes to the initial template. Docusaurus has much more to offer! Have 5 more minutes? Take a look at versioning and i18n. Anything unclear or buggy in this tutorial? Please report it!

Read the official documentation Modify your site configuration with docusaurus.config.js Add navbar and footer items with themeConfig Add a custom Design and Layout Add a search bar Find inspirations in the Docusaurus showcase Get involved in the Docusaurus Community
Docusaurus creates a page for each blog post, but also a blog index page, a tag system, an RSS feed...

Create a file at blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md: blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md --- slug: greetings title: Greetings! authors: - name: Joel Marcey title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1 url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey image_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey.png - name: S√©bastien Lorber title: Docusaurus maintainer url: https://sebastienlorber.com image_url: https://github.com/slorber.png tags: [greetings] --- Congratulations, you have made your first post! Feel free to play around and edit this post as much as you like. A new blog post is now available at http://localhost:3000/blog/greetings.
Documents are groups of pages connected through: a sidebar previous/next navigation versioning
Create a Markdown file at docs/hello.md: docs/hello.md # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**! A new document is now available at http://localhost:3000/docs/hello.

Docusaurus automatically creates a sidebar from the docs folder. Add metadata to customize the sidebar label and position: docs/hello.md --- sidebar_label: 'Hi!' sidebar_position: 3 --- # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**! It is also possible to create your sidebar explicitly in sidebars.js: sidebars.js export default { tutorialSidebar: [ 'intro', 'hello', { type: 'category', label: 'Tutorial', items: ['tutorial-basics/create-a-document'], }, ], };
Add Markdown or React files to src/pages to create a standalone page: src/pages/index.js ‚Üí localhost:3000/ src/pages/foo.md ‚Üí localhost:3000/foo src/pages/foo/bar.js ‚Üí localhost:3000/foo/bar

Create a file at src/pages/my-react-page.js: src/pages/my-react-page.js import React from 'react'; import Layout from '@theme/Layout'; export default function MyReactPage() { return (

My React page

This is a React page

 ); } A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-react-page.
Create a file at src/pages/my-markdown-page.md: src/pages/my-markdown-page.md # My Markdown page This is a Markdown page A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-markdown-page.
Docusaurus is a static-site-generator (also called Jamstack). It builds your site as simple static HTML, JavaScript and CSS files.
Build your site for production: npm run build The static files are generated in the build folder.

Test your production build locally: npm run serve The build folder is now served at http://localhost:3000/. You can now deploy the build folder almost anywhere easily, for free or very small cost (read the Deployment Guide).
Docusaurus supports Markdown and a few additional features.

Markdown documents have metadata at the top called Front Matter: my-doc.md --- id: my-doc-id title: My document title description: My document description slug: /my-custom-url --- ## Markdown heading Markdown text with [links](./hello.md)

Regular Markdown links are supported, using url paths or relative file paths. Let's see how to [Create a page](/create-a-page). Let's see how to [Create a page](./create-a-page.md). Result: Let's see how to Create a page.

Regular Markdown images are supported. You can use absolute paths to reference images in the static directory (static/img/docusaurus.png): ![Docusaurus logo](/img/docusaurus.png) You can reference images relative to the current file as well. This is particularly useful to colocate images close to the Markdown files using them: ![Docusaurus logo](./img/docusaurus.png)

Markdown code blocks are supported with Syntax highlighting. ```jsx title="src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js" function HelloDocusaurus() { return

Hello, Docusaurus!

; } ``` src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js function HelloDocusaurus() { return

Hello, Docusaurus!

; }

Docusaurus has a special syntax to create admonitions and callouts: :::tip[My tip] Use this awesome feature option ::: :::danger[Take care] This action is dangerous ::: My tip Use this awesome feature option Take care This action is dangerous

MDX can make your documentation more interactive and allows using any React components inside Markdown: export const Highlight = ({children, color}) => ( { alert(`You clicked the color ${color} with label ${children}`) }}> {children} ); This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue ! This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue !
Let's translate docs/intro.md to French.
Modify docusaurus.config.js to add support for the fr locale: docusaurus.config.js export default { i18n: { defaultLocale: 'en', locales: ['en', 'fr'], }, };

Copy the docs/intro.md file to the i18n/fr folder: mkdir -p i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/ cp docs/intro.md i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md Translate i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md in French.

Start your site on the French locale: npm run start -- --locale fr Your localized site is accessible at http://localhost:3000/fr/ and the Getting Started page is translated. caution In development, you can only use one locale at a time.

To navigate seamlessly across languages, add a locale dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'localeDropdown', }, ], }, }, }; The locale dropdown now appears in your navbar:
Build your site for a specific locale: npm run build -- --locale fr Or build your site to include all the locales at once: npm run build
Docusaurus can manage multiple versions of your docs.

Release a version 1.0 of your project: npm run docusaurus docs:version 1.0 The docs folder is copied into versioned_docs/version-1.0 and versions.json is created. Your docs now have 2 versions: 1.0 at http://localhost:3000/docs/ for the version 1.0 docs current at http://localhost:3000/docs/next/ for the upcoming, unreleased docs

To navigate seamlessly across versions, add a version dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'docsVersionDropdown', }, ], }, }, }; The docs version dropdown appears in your navbar:

It is possible to edit versioned docs in their respective folder: versioned_docs/version-1.0/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/hello docs/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/next/hello
